text:
My husband's Irish mom made him shepherd's pie when he was a wee little boy. After 28 years of marriage, I decided to make it. He LOVED it! More importantly, he loved it more than his mom! I changed a few things to make it ours. To the potatoes I added about 1/2 tbl of onion powder, butter, cheese, salt and pepper. To the sauteed onions, I added about 1 tsp of minced garlic. I had to use 2 tbl of oil for the onions and garlic, 1 tbl was not enough. I felt the meat was a bit bland, so I spinkled some onion and garlic powder and about 1/2 tbl of worcestershire sauce. I also used 3 tbl of flour, not two. I sprinkled frozen peas and carrots on top of the meat, because the other way is just too time consuming. We felt that there was not enough meat. So next time I'll try 2 pounds of meat. I also added more than 1/4 c. of cheese to the top of the mashed potatoes. My husband devoured it. Will be making it for this upcoming St. Patty's Day!

Delicious! city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe gets 5 stars but only based on all the changes the other reviewers made, which i definitely appreciated! I omitted the beef broth and instead added 1/2 cup worsesterchire sauce to the meat as it was almost done browning, then added 2 tbsp ketchup, 2 small cloves of minced garlic, 1 packet of 50% reduced sodium brown gravy, 1 cup of water, and the flour as the recipe calls for and allowed it to thicken a bit. 
As for the potatoes, 4 large were too many for me. I could've easily gotten by with 3 as I had some leftover. I didn't follow the directions in the recipe for the potatoes, instead, I made these based on how i'd typically make homemade mashed potatoes - milk, lots of butter, and salt and pepper to taste, then i added the 1/4 cup of cheese.
And instead of the carrot mash, I used frozen peas, corn, and carrots and put a layer on top of the meat before topping off with the mashed potatoes in the casserole dish. Finally, when it was ready to go in the oven i put a thin layer of cheese on top and cooked it at 375 for about 25-30. Delicious!

I did modify the recipe..because you do NOT use ketchup in Shepherd's Pie!  I used HP sauce which is readily available in most grocery stories; it is a British 'sauce' similar to A1, but not quite and we actually prefer the HP.  Didn't have carrots, so I used frozen mixed veggies, thawed, in place of the carrots..Which turned it into Cottage Pie, as my Brit cousin and his friends informed me, but it was good!  It will be made again..

userID:
15717626
Display Name:
Arge
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0

0
favoritesCount:
5
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3544068.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe probably a dozen times since I've discovered it and it's definitely one of my favorites. A few small tweaks to the recipe for my preference:

I substitute gravy powder for the flour for the thickening agent.
I eyeball a bit of Worcestershire sauce to the ground beef mixture while it's simmering with the thickening agent.
Instead of mashing the carrots, I add in fresh diced carrots, peas and corn to the ground beef mixture close to when you transfer the mixture into the casserole dish. 
Lastly, instead of sprinkling the cheese on top before putting it in the oven, I allow it to bake for the 20 minutes, then add cheese afterwards, throwing it into the oven on broil for about 5 minutes to give a slight crust to the cheese and potatoes. 

I really do enjoy this recipe quite a bit. Had some friends over that also enjoyed it. I do recommend!
Review:

5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
All the elements are here for a great classic.  A few tweaks:  if you have kids that balk at 'mashed carrots', leave them out, or at least reduce by half the amount (might just use cut carrots rather than the mash)... or as others have suggested swap in peas and corn for the carrot.  Gotta get the mince to potato proportion right.... go bigger on the mince.  And be generous with the broth.... I found the 5 minute reduction, even on a slow simmer, used up a lot of the yummy sauce that makes mince sing... you need that gravy.  Added a few rosemary leaves to the mince when reducing, once more to bring home the classic shepherd's pie character.  Cheese on top could be replaced with a drizzle of butter, and end with a minute or two under the broiler to brown to perfection.  All the elements, just tweak it, and enjoy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a guide not following it so much,  but we all enjoyed it, and will make again. My husband would like me to try it with turkey next time. Four stars since I didn't really make the recipe. 

I used Yukon Golds for the mashed potatos; cooking water,  2% milk, and a good dollap of butter. Someone gave me a bunch of flavored sea salt, so I added a good amount of Hawaiian bamboo jade, and lots of fresh cracked white pepper.

I cooked the carrots in the potato water and mashed lightly so they were still chunky. 

I slow cooked a large white onion so it was almost translucent then partilally carmelized. Added the beef and cooked; a couple pinches of flour, the beef broth (reconstituted crystals). I did use the ketchup (probably tomato paste next time), plus a bunch of shakes of Wosteshire, and a couple shakes of a Louisiana hot sauce. Both fresh cracked black and white pepper,  and some garlic medley sea salt. I thin sliced, then lightly chopped, 3/4 of a small head of green cabbage, and added it to the beef, and cooked another few minutes. 

I layered half the beef mix, all the carrots,  the rest of beef mix, and typed with the potatos.

The eight year old enjoyed it too.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent shepherd's pie. My husband, who claims not to like shepherd's pie, couldn't get enough of it, and my two young ones ate it well too. I had a bunch of leftover veggies, so I threw them all into the veg/meat mixture: 1/2 onion (chopped), bunch of baby carrots (sliced), mushrooms (sliced), green onions (green and white parts, chopped fine). I also added approximately one cup frozen corn and let it cook with the other veggies. I then added 1 lb ground beef, 2 T ketchup, 2 T flour, 1/4 c worcestershire sauce, 1 packet of mushroom gravy mix, and 1.5 c water. Once everything was cooked and the sauce thickened, I poured into a greased pan, scooped the potatoes (I already had mashed potatoes leftover in the fridge), dotted with butter, sprinkled with shredded cheese (Mexican blend), and ta-da! amazing shepherd's pie!

text:
I had every intention of following the recipe exactly.  However, I started scrolling through the reviews and strayed.  It was a good stray though.  I added the brown gravy packet to the meat along w/a cup of water.  And, I eliminated the onions from the mashed potatoes.  The family loved it.  I would normally go back and try it as written.  But this recipe is so easy to personalize, I may even incorporate some ideas of my own.  I thought about adding some of the Lipton's Beefy Onion soup mix to the ground beef instead of beef broth and ketchup.  Once again, I realize that this changes the game, however, making changes to suit your family's preference isn't a bad thing either.  Loved this recipe!!!

text:
This is regularly my go-to recipe since it's so simple, but I always find my meat mixture lacking in flavor.  I can never seem to season it well enough (my fault I'm sure!).  I decided to replace all the meat with Johnsonville Sausage, and it made a HUGE difference in flavor!  I opted for a Johnsonville Bratwurst since this is essentially "pub food," and despite not being a beer drinker, the beer flavor inside the sausage infused the dish beautifully, and this is how I plan to make it from now on, using various Johnsonville Sausage flavors to see what they all do.

text:
This recipe is very good and like other recipe's of Shepherd's Pie it can be a tad bland.  Next time I make it I may add a 1/2 envelope of onion soup mix to give it a little more zip.  I followed the recipe to a T as far as ingredients however, I cooked the carrots with the onions and did not mash them.  After adding the beef they melted in your mouth.  I saw no need to add the step of mashing them and layering them separately.  I will be trying this again with the onion soup mix and see what happens.

text:
Wow. We made this for supper last night and it was phenomenal! Would rate it a 6 star on a 5 star scale.  There are so many variations you could make from the types of meat you use to the vegetables you add as well as the spices you use.  Compared to the real deal in Scotland fixed with lamb, this is hands-down much better.  My husband, who is the real cook in the family, keeps his mashed potatoes on the moist side with half and half and butter to avoid the dryness that can happen with Shepherds pie or any casserole for that matter. Of course this adds many calories as well. He made a huge casserole dish of this and it was all gone by the end of the meal.  No leftovers to mess with, that's for sure! It says a lot when you can keep teen-age boys happy!

text:
Fantastic!  I was short on potatoes, so I added a couple garnet yams to the mashed potato layer.  It made it orange, but was really tasty.  Opted for frozen mixed veggies instead of the mashed carrots (especially since there were yams in my potatoes), and added worchestshire sauce as recommended by others as well as some gravy helper.  Topped it with Smoked Beechers Flagship cheese which really added a whole new level to all the flavors.  On day three of leftovers and still excited for my lunch today!

text:
I made this with some of the additions that were recommended.  Also, I didn't have ground beef so I used beef chunks, sauted with onions, garlic, 2 beef cubes and 2 tbls. flour to thicken.  I steamed fresh carrots and sliced them instead of mashing.  I added sour cream and seasoning to the mash potatoes and sprinkled with paprika.  All in all it turned out great and my kids loved it. I will try this again with ground beef next time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I love this recipe!! We made it for St. Patricks day last year and I am making it again for him today because it is a nice cold day. I changed the recipe slightly based off a few other reviewers comments. 

First off let me say that it is very important to properly season your food with salt and pepper throughout the cooking process. I salt and pepper my meat before cooking as well as generously salt the water for the potatoes before putting them in. Unfortunately people have been lead to believe that salt is bad for you, not the case. Too much salt is bad, yes. But a generous pinch of kosher salt to any meat or vegetable brings out all the flavor most of you probably  missed out on when you made it the first time. Add flavor whenever possible, I also boil my carrots in chicken stock which gives them an amazing added umph!  

Other additions include; most if not all of 1 packet of brown (beef) gravy, a little extra Ketchup and a a few splashes to 1/4 cup Worcestershire sauce to the beef as it is browning. 

Hope you all enjoy! It's one of the most amazing meals you can make if you do it right.

text:
Very tasty recipe! I took some advice from the previous reviewers: I added 1/4 cup worcestershire sauce to the meat before cooking and mixed well; instead of beef broth, I poured in half a jar of meat gravy and probably 1/4 to 1/2 cup of water from boiling the potatoes and let simmer 5 minutes (I also did add a tbsp of ketchup while cooking); and instead of cooked and mashed carrots I poured a mix of frozen vegetables to cover the meat to cover (did not thaw/microwave beforehand). Overall, it was really delicious and I am going to add it to my list of dinnertime favorites. I can't wait to make it again. Thank you very much for the recipe!

text:
Love it! Hubby has never had Shepards pie before(Its not really known in Eastern Europe) but he LOVED it! And now keeps requesting it! I mostly followed the recipe. Though i added the Worchestireshire to make the mince more 'Meat Pieish'(Im Aussie). And I whipped the Potatoes with the Electric mixer to make them much more smooth and creamy. I added some breadcrumbs on top with the cheese as well. Give it a bit of a crunchy texture on top to break up the softness.
Love it and great recipe! Easy to make and great leftovers(If theres any left!)

text:
Excellent - this is the epitome of comfort food, and there's no better way to use leftover mashed potatoes. Like others suggested, I cooked the onion with some garlic, and omitted the beef broth and used a combination of 1/4 c Worcestershire, 1 cup water,1 packet of brown gravy mix, and a splash of port for a little more complexity. I also added a bag of frozen peas - which I think gave the dish some much needed color and texture. Very, very good.

country:
None
text:
I modified almost everything about this recipe to make it time-friendly for work night dinner. I left out the onion, water, salt & pepper- substituting beef broth and onion soup mix. I added 1 3/4 cups frozen mixed vegetables while simmering the cooked beef in the broth mixture, and prepared a box mashed potato mix at that time. I folded 1/4 cup shredded cheddar cheese into the potatoes. I then spread the beef & vegetable mixture into a 9" pie plate, topped with another 1/4 cup cheddar cheese and the potatoes. Baked as directed, and the whole process took less than 40 minutes-yum!!

text:
This is a good recipe.  I made a few adjustments based on other reviewers' suggestions.  I used a packet of brown gravy instead of the beef broth and prepared it as instructed on the packet.  I then add the gravy to my browned meat along with 1 tbs each of worcestershire, A1 and ketchup.  I often will pay with the ratios of the three until its to my liking.  My family likes garlic mashed potatoes so I add a few into my potatoes while they boil instead of adding onions to it.  For the veggies, I used 1 12oz bag of frozen peas & carrots.  This is a great dish to prepare ahead of time and put into the oven later.

This turned out really good. I did make a few adjustments, hence the 4 stars. Without the adjustments, it likely would've been too bland. I added 1/4 cup Worcestershire Sauce to the ground beef after mixing in the flour. I also heavily seasoned it with salt and pepper. I added garlic to the onion when cooking. I also mixed a tad bit of milk and garlic powder into the mashed potatoes. I also broiled the top at the end to get a nice brown top. I will definitely make this again but use less carrots and more meat mixture.

text:
This is a great recipe.  Instead of using water, I used 1 1/4 cups dark beer - Dogfish Head Indian Brown Ale and it made the pie incredibly hearty, almost like a steak and Guinness pie.  Following the advice of other reviewers I added 1/4 cup of worcestershire sauce, 2 tablespoons of ketchup, 2 tablespoons of flour and a brown gravy packet.  I will make this many times over.

Easy to make and so delicious! I halved the recipe as it is just me and my husband. I didn't have ketchup or flour or onion. So I used what I had. Thank you for the recipe. It will become a regular in this house!

text:
Good. Not fancy, but what do you expect? Peeling, boiling, and layering is about all there is to it. I like this because you get almost your whole meal in 1-2 scoops of this. Furthermore, the boiling method doesnt dirty the pans, just a quick wash and rinse. Now if you can simmer the ground beef in something that is oven-ready (like a dutch oven) you can cut down on one more pan (the one for the ground beef) and just serve from the dutch oven. Just a thought if youre like me and HATE doing dishes.

text:
Delish! My mom said it could be her last meal :) I did change some things to suit our taste. 1- sauteed shallots and garlic in some evoo. 2- added the ground beef into the shallot & garlic mix and cooked. 3- remove from heat and added frozen corn and peas after beef was cooked. 4- removed beef mix leaving liquid behind to make sauce using ketchup, beef broth & beef bisto for thickening 5- made instant mash, added butter, salt & pepper, as well as some pureed garlic in evoo. 6- put beef mix in first (when removed from liquid), then sauces over top, then potato mix with shredded cheddar cheese. It was to die for!! Made it again tonight to freeze :)

text:
This was excellent!  Really nice recipe.  I prepared it a bit differently from the recipe according to which ingredients I had on hand, and the suggestions of other reviewers.  I used cubed beef and seasoned it.  Browned it with onion in a little olive oil.  Once browned, I added a couple tbl flour, 1/2 beef bullion cube, 1.5 cup water, ketchup, and bag of frozen peas.  Let that boil down so that it had a gravy.  Used a packet of potato flakes on top.  Excellent dish!  Next time add a bit more salt and pepper, and maybe experiment with adding other veggies.

text:
never reviewed before, but i felt i had to on this one because it's just missing a tiny little something to make it perfect. i gave this 4 stars as is, because i think it's a fantastic start. the only thing about it i disliked was how dry it was. so, i added much more butter to the potatoes, and some milk as well, until the creaminess was to my liking. then for the meat, i added 2 sticks of celery, and didn't drain it (i buy the super lean), because i didn't want to lose all the liquid from the onions and celery. lastly i added 2 more TBS of ketchup. it turned out much more moist and delicious than when i followed the recipe exactly. i highly recommend trying it this way. :)

None
text:
When I first saw this recipe I thought it would be a ton of work, but don't be intimidated - it is so easy and quick! I have been using this as my base recipe for ages now and will never buy pre-made pie again.  Don't be afraid to fool around with this one - I don't bother putting a separate layer of carrots anymore, I just saute whatever veggies I have on hand in with the beef after it's browned. The only change I think you MUST make to this is to add worcestershire sauce or other seasoning of your choice, or it will be too bland. A side note - this is actually a recipe for Cottage Pie, not Shepherd's Pie. Shepherd's Pie is made with lamb, not beef, but you could easily substitute either.

Pretty good!  Instead of ground beef, I used 3 steak sandwich steaks (6 oz. each) which had defrosted and needed to be used.  I added 1/2 & 1/2 to the mashed potatoes. This was really amazing and super easy. I did take other's advice and chose to add sour cream in the potatoes.  I also used more cheese (2 cups total) and instead of carrots, I used corn.  I definitely recommend using the brown gravy as opposed to the broth (I think it's more flavorful).  I also added montreal steak seasoning to the beef mixture...it gave it such a great flavor.  I have been wanting to make sheperd's pie for years (mom used to make it) and my family turned their noses up every time I'd suggest it. Made it for the first time on Monday...and it was GONE. They loved it so much that I was asked to make it twice in the same week. Thanks Jacquie!

city:

country:

text:
This is what I did.  Turned out pretty good.  1) Cast iron skillet.  Cook 1 lb lean ground sirloin with chopped 1/2 sweet onion, lowery's salt, fresh grnd pepper, dash of ray's seasoning.  Stir 2 Tbs flour into to 3/4 cup water, salt and pepper and add to beef mixture.  2) Used 8 red potatoes.  Steamed and then mashed with skins on.  Added 1Tbs butter, salt, pepper, lowery's salt, 1 small onion minced, enough milk to moisten.  Mixed in 1/4 cup shredded cheddar.  3) Steamed 4 carrots.  Mashed with skins on.  4) Layer carrot, and then potatoes on beef mixture in iron skillet.  Add other 1/4 cheese on top.   Cook in skillet in  oven at 375 for 20 min.

This an excellent base recipe and the cheddar cheese is a MUST (it browns so nicely in the oven). However, this recipe is missing vital compenents. Worcestercire sauce is a big one...I've never seen it NOT used in a shepherds pie recipe. About a tablespoon or so for this recipe would do nicely. I also like to add green peas for a splash of color (even though they are not traditional).

text:
I gave this 4 stars because I made some changes to it to get it just right.  Like many other reviewers I added 1/4 cup worchestershire sauce, 2 Tablespoons of ketchup, and 1 crushed clove of garlic to the meat mixture.  I did add sour cream to the mashed potatoes because mine seemed to dry.  Next time I would omit the onion in the potatoe mixture too. It is a tad on the blad side....so dont be afraid to add the full 1/4 cup worchestershire sauce.  I have yet to try it but I think making it with the gravy instead of the broth, like others have suggested, would add a nice punch of flavor.

country:
None
text:
Very good!  I tweaked the recipe a bit, and it was a winner.  I used red potatoes, left the skin on, and mixed in a bit of milk with them while mashing.  I also doubled the diced onion and cheese in the mashed potatoes.  I added 2 cloves of minced garlic to the sauteed onion, and added some basil and oregano to the meat while it browned.  I used a packet of brown gravy mix, with 3/4 cup of water instead of beef broth.  I was out of ketchup, so I used pasta sauce instead.  I also used a 16 oz package of peas and carrots over the beef mixture, and probably tripled the cheese topping, also throwing in mozerella and jack in with the cheddar.

text:
This recipe was a huge success in our house!!  Following the advice of other reviewers, I added sour cream to the mashed potatoes and Worchestershire sauce to the meat.  I also added peas, topped with black pepper and chives... this was the most flavorful Sheperd's Pie I've ever had!  I'm sure it would be perfect as-is, but come on... sour cream and Worchestershire - how can you resist!?  My boyfriend loved it! - Even after he made a face, when I told him what was for dinner, and said he didn't like Shepherd's Pie!  Thank you so much for helping me add another great staple to my recipe collection!

text:
This is a great one dish meal for a casual supper.  I added chopped fresh mushrooms to the sauteed ions and sauteed the carrots with some frozen green peas for color and did not mash but layered them over the beef layer. Potatoes were a bit stiff so I added a little milk to give it beter spreadability on the top.  Make sure to use sharp cheddar.  Crumbled  cooked bacon on the top gives this dish a delicious finish.

I thought it tasted okay but was just a little bland...next time I will add more spices to the meat :)

DEEEEEELISH!!  The changes suggested by others make this sooo good.  I replaced beef broth and flour with gravy mix w/1 c water and added 1/4c Worcestershire sauce. text:
Following other reviewers - I made some changes as well.  Sauteed a few cloves of crushed garlic with an onion in 1 tbsp of vegetable oil before adding the beef.  Drain. I added a few shakes of paprika, then added 1 packet of brown gravy mix with 1 cup of water. 2 tbsp of Ketchup (I do not think Worcester sauce belonged in Shepherd's Pie so I did not add it, unlike most reviewers who did) Then I put in a 12 oz bag of frozen mixed veggies (the kind with corn, carrots, peas and green beans in it). I did not add flour, I felt it didn't need it. Simmered it for about 5 mins. I layered this on the bottom of a 9x13 pan, then topped with my mashed potatoes (I didn't add onions to it, only mixed in the butter and cheddar cheese).  The cheese is enough to not have to add salt (in my opinion). Topped with more cheese and baked at 375 for 20 min. Came out perfect and delicious!  WONDERFUL for the Fall Holiday season!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
EASY EASY EASY!!! and GREAT!! I used instant potatoes (my mother would DIE!) I used a packet of mushroom gravy and added 1 cup of warm water to it and set it aside while i cooked the meat. To the gravy i added ketchup, a small jar of mushrooms, and some A1 sauce... didn't have HP. I used a  steambag of veggies from the freezer section (carrots, corn, and asparagus) I added the flour to the meat, then the gravy mixture and heated through. Then dumped the bag of veggies in with the meat before pouring it in the bottom of the pan. Then added potatoes on top followed by more cheese.... I know the foodies out there would "tisk tisk" me for going the easy route, but the bag of veggies made it! Also love the crunch of uncooked onion in the potato topping!! GREAT!!

text:
I made this last night and it was soooo good. Great comfort food. I did make a few changes. I used instant potatoes (only because they were easier; not because I like them better than the real thing). I also used a package of frozen mixed veggies. I added a whole can of beef broth with the ground beef and while that was simmering, I added the veggies so they would cook a little. To thicken up the meat mixture and add some more flavor, I added a packet of brown gravy. I'm looking forward to the leftovers for lunch today!

text:
This recipe for Shepherd Pie was excellent! I used 1.5 lbs. of ground chuck and then drained it. I used 1 whole can of beef broth, the brown gravy packet, 2/3 cup of water and 1/4 cup of worchestershire sauce. I cooked it until some of the liquid had reduced and added 2 tbs. of flour. I used peas, carrots and corn mixed in with the meat. I wouldn't use instant mashed potatoes in this recipe as some reviews suggested, but that's just personal preference. I added the cheddar cheese, sour cream, butter and green onions to the mashed potatoes and it turned out wonderful. I will definitely make this recipe again.

country:
None
text:
Really, really good. i used half ground lamb, and half a pound of very lean ground sirloin. there was so little grease that I did not need to drain it off. Added three cloves of garlic, at least a quarter cup of worstershire sauce, one onion and a one teaspoon of dried thyme as I cooked the meat mixture. the thyme is fantastic. i also added about a half cup sour cream, two tablespoons butter and some milk to get the right consistency on the mashed potatoes. left the onion out of the potatoes. i stuck with the beef broth and thought it worked out great. I used chopped fresh carrots - right out of the garden so they were tender and sweet - and a handful of peas instead of mashed carrots. Topped it with a little extra cheese and paprika as others suggested. Will definitely make it again despite it being time consuming.

text:
Very good, but I have to admit I changed some things. First, I used instant mashed potatoes. Second, I used frozen veggies. I sauteed the beef and onions as instructed, but added broiled steak seasoning and some salt free beef bouillon and water (instead of broth) to the mix along with the flour and ketchup. It made a very nice gravy. I poured that into my dish, layered the frozen vegetables in, then the potatoes, then the cheese and some paprika. I baked the result (which was very pretty) covered for 10 minutes at 325 to steam the veggies a little and then uncovered for 20 minutes at 375 as the recipe instructs. This was SO good! Will definitely be making again! A+

userID:
1074124
Display Name:
CAROL
isPro:
False

0

34
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for the first time on St. Pat's Day, and it was very good. I'm giving it four rather than five stars because I think it needs quite a bit of tweaking to be really tasty. So, based on other reviewers' suggestions and my own preferences, I added the 1/4 C worchestershire to the raw meat; then, to the browning meat, garlic, extra ketchup, seasoning salt, a bit more broth--I had chicken broth, so that's what I used, with 1 t beef boullion--and, because of the extra broth, an extra T flour. I substituted a can of mixed vegetables (drained) for the carrots. I made the pie itself in an 8" cast-iron pan on the stove, topped with the mashed potatoes I'd made earlier, then popped it into the oven for about 15 minutes to heat it through and to brown the top. (No need to transfer to a casserole dish and have to wash another item.) It looked really neat (and maybe more "authentic") served in the skillet. And one note: Probably because I doubled the cheese and added extra broth, when I took it out of the oven, it was pretty wet--I couldn't cut it into wedges. But I found that after the pan sat on the stove for an hour or so, the pie absorbed the extra liquid and could then be cut into wedges. So its form was better later on, and the leftovers microwaved perfectly. Anyway, this recipe is really easy to follow, prepare, and tweak to your own tastes.  Everyone here liked it a lot.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-03-22T05:08:29.29
helpfulCount:
1

text:
Wow-what a great recipe!  I followed the recipe pretty close, but did make a few changes. Instead of carrots I used frozen chopped veggies (green beans, carrots, etc.).  As others have suggested, I added 1/4 c. worcheshire sauce and two good squirts of ketchup to the ground beef.  I ended up using 2 lbs of ground beef and almost a whole can of beef broth.  I also seasoned the beef with a few sprinkles of onion powder (in addition to the chopped onion).  When it comes to the potatoes, I doubled them and also added extra butter, onion, salt, pepper, and cheese.  Then, in a big casserole dish I put the beef on the bottom, then the cooked veggies, then the potatoes.  I finished it off with a sprinkle of paprika and shredded monterey jack cheese.  This dish will be a new staple for our house!  It smells so good while it cooks and tastes delicious!

text:
My husband absolutely detests cooked carrots so I substituted sweet corn.  I roasted a small head of garlic and added it to the mashed potatoes instead of minced onion and since I used ground chicken breast I used chicken broth.  I forgot to add the ketchup but can't see how it would have made it better. Overall this was a good make ahead dish.  I simply reheated it in the oven and ended with it under the broiler for a couple minutes.  My husband said it would be better with more cheese on top but then what isn't better with a little extra cheese?  Definitely recommend the roasted garlic. (Simply cut tops off garlic to expose individual cloves, drizzle with olive oil, wrap in foil and bake in 400 degree oven until soft)

This recipes is very good. I read through the reviews first and decided on the following: Cooked ground turkey in a skillet, added 1 diced carrot, 4oz corn, 4oz can of mushrooms, sauteed all. Then added 2T flour, 1 packet beef gravy, 2T ketchup, 2T worchestershire, and 1 cup beef broth. I allowed this to simmer 10 mins or so. I used boxed potatoes. Poured beef mixture in baking dish topped with potatoes and covered with shredded colby jack cheese. YUMMY! With all of the extra added to beef mixture it was very flavorful. My 9 year old ate it, so it's a keeper!! Thanks!! Oh, The flour is a must, so the beef mixture stays firm and not runny!!

Great Shepherd's Pie recipe. Only thing I would change is the taste of the ground beef. It is kind of bland plain. Will add herbs to give it a punch. I also wouldnt take any recommendation on using canned and instant potatoes, that pretty much cuts down your nutrition to just protein...If you're trying to feed your family do it properly with fresh carrots and potatoes. None
text:
This was my first attempt at Shepherd's Pie. I made a few modifications & a couple mistakes but it still turned out great! My husband is a very picky eater from Africa and most American dishes do not have enough 'taste' for him but he really liked this dish. I will definitely be making this again. I took a few shortcuts; some for time and some by mistake or necessity. I used instant potatoes, canned peas & carrots, forgot to use flour at all, used boullion but increased the ketchup to 1/4 cup. I also used vinegar in the ground beef - vinegar brings out the flavor in all meats, I use it a lot. Without the flour it was a little wetter than it was supposed to be but it was still very good. I added garlic powder & chopped onion to the potatoes and sprinkled them with a small amount of shredded cheddar 15 minutes before it was done. It will be fun to try this different ways. I am enjoying this website and all the reviews are SO helpful!! Thanks to everyone who offers feedback and thanks to those who put the site together. Kudos to all of you.

text:
This was a wonderful recipe!  I used a variation of it to fit my family's tastes.  As the ground beef was browning, I added 2 diced onions and 3 cloves of garlic.  Once the ground beef was browned and the onions clear, I added 1 can of mixed veggies, 2 cans of string beans, 1 can of corn, and 2 packages of gravy mix with 2 cups of water.  I also used seasoning salt, red pepper flakes, black pepper, cumin, onion and garlic powders.  I let this mixture cook for 5-10 minutes.  I then put in in the baking dish with the mashed potatoes and cheddar cheese.  It was WONDERFULLY seasoned.  This recipe gave me a basic outline for which my family and I are thankful!

text:
We really liked this one...even though I tweaked it big time. I sauteed onion,diced green pepper,and garlic in a little evoo. Added the cooked and drained ground beef to that. I had no beef broth, only a pack of dry brown gravy mix, which I made according to the pack. I added the ketchup to the beef mixture and added 1/2 a bag of frozen mixed veggies (corn,green beans,peas,carrots). I then added the brown gravy,salt and pepper. Placed that mixture in a casserole dish and topped with a pack of instant mashed potatoes which I made according to the package. Added a little more butter to the top and shredded cheese. Covered and baked until bubbely. Everyone really enjoyed this. Good comfort food. Thanks!

I had never made this before until last night, and WOW was it a hit! I changed to recipe to my taste because I am very picky. I definitely recommend draining the meat once it's cooked...I didn't due to time constraints and I ended up with a thin concoction.  I also simmered the peas and carrots with the gravy.

country:
None
text:
With the modifications we made, I'd give this recipe all five stars. We used instant mashed potatoes just to save on time and seasoned with butter, garlic, salt and pepper to taste. Insteat of the carrots we used a 16 oz bag of mixed veggies (i.e. corn, green beans, and carrots) and added them in with the meat. Instead of the beef broth we used the package of brown gravy mix as suggested by others BUT with it we used 1/8 cup worcestershire sauce, 1/2 cup water and 1/2 cup red wine (we recently had shepher's pie at a restaurant and it definitely had red wine in it) With these changes it came out so yummy that my 11 year old had four servings. THAT is a keeper!

text:
I fixed this for my in-laws. They all said it was great. I followed some of the suggestions from other reviewers. I mixed 1/4 cup worstershire in my hamburger meat before starting anything else. I didn't add onion to my potatoes as hubby doesn't like onions that much. I also only used 1/2 an onion instead of all of one. I used brown gravy mix w/1 cup water instead of beef broth. I added 1/2 bag frozen peas and carrots on top of meat mixture before covering with potatoes instead of just carrots. Easy to make and turned out great!

text:
I changed it a bit as per other people's suggestions so it only gets 4 stars. I added 1/4 cup of Worstechire (sp?) sauce and a bit more broth to make a gravy. I sauteed the carrot & onion in some EVOO took them out and then browned the meat and put them back in with some chopped garlic. Make a very moist and delicious filling. I also made my mashed potatoes more flavorful by adding some heavy cream (1/4 cup) (could use milk or sour cream too)and some garlic powder. I omitted the cheese from the recipe because it didnt need it and I topped it with some sprinkles of paprika and chives for color and it added a great looking color on top.

text:
Great comfort food!  I followed this recipe using ground lean turkey and without mashing the carrots (I cut them up and cooked them in beef broth to make them more tender before adding to the turkey mixture) and I also added some lima beans (you could add almost any veggie you like).  I made clean-up easier by using a deep oven-safe frying pan to brown the turkey and simply adding the veggies and mashed potatoes to the pan) - this was delicious and a breeze to make.  Will DEFINTELY make again!!

Very yummy meal, good for a cold day. I did make the following changes: I used corn instead of carrots, just a personal preference. I couldnt help but add milk and some garlic powder to the potatoes!! I added a little beef gravy to the meat mixture and omitted the ketchup. 
I found that there were a lot of potatoes and not a lot of meat. When I make this again, I would add at least another 1/2 lb. of meat. I give it a 4 out of 5 only because it didnt WOW me, it seemed to lack a little flavor. Very simple recipe. I served with homemade biscuits. Very yummy will make again!

I took the advice of several others and used gravy instead of beef broth.  Also, I mixed the carrots (which I microwaved instead of boiled) with 1/2 cup of frozen peas (my husband is not a big fan of peas) and a can of corn.  I added lots of garlic powder to the beef mixture and sprinkled some on the veggies as well.  I will likely make this in the future, but plan on leaving out the carrots.

text:
Great recipe!  I made a few alterations as per previous reviewers, i.e., adding a garlic clove to the beef and onions and bumping the ketchup up to 1/4c.  I also used two cans of diced peas and carrots in place of the boiled and mashed carrots - saved a ton of time and effort and was more visually appealing to my 21-month old.  I also omitted the onions in the potatoes but added a little drizzled butter over the top to add a bit more flavor.  To my great delight, my very picky 21-month old ate almost all of it!  This will definitely be a staple in my house - thanks much!

This is one of the best recipe's I have gotten off of this site. The only thing I changed in the recipe is instead of 3/4 Cup of beef broth, I just boiled 3/4 C. water and mixed it with 6 beef boullion cubes. I would also like to add that as a mother of a 4 year old and 1 year old twins (2 of the 3 are picky eaters) they all gobbled it up and my 4 year old actually asked for more (he hasn't even done that with pizza!) OK, enough. I love it. 5 stars all the way.

country:
None
text:
This shepherds pie was quite good - with some changes :)  We had mashed potatoes already left over from Christmas dinner, so I used those and didn't add the onion or the cheese to them.  To the ground beef mixture, I added a lot more onion than what was called for, 1/4 cup of ketchup, 1/4 cup of worcestershire and 1 large clove of garlic (and salt and pepper of course); I also increased the beef broth to 1 cup for added flavour.  Although I did add the mashed carrots and some peas on top of that, my husband and I didn't find the carrots added any flavour at all, so next time, I will probably try it with a can of creamed corn or something. I didn't sprinkle any shredded cheese on top of the potatoes as I have found in the past that the cheese does not add any additional flavour, so I sprinkled about 1/4 cup of parmesan cheese - this added a really nice flavour.

I did as another reviewer suggested  and added 1/4 cup worcestershire to the ground beef and a packet of brown gravy mixed with 1 cup water instead of beef broth. I like ease so I left out the onions (didn't want to chop and recipe didn't miss them) I used canned mixed vegetables for second layer. I used a 8oz sour cream in mashed potatoes and some half and half to make it creamier. (Do this right before you are going to add the mashed layer so it is creamy and spreads on top easier) I put a pat of butter on top and didn't measure just covered top with shredded sharp cheddar cheese. DELICIOUS.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to say that this is a wonderful recipe, even when you mess it all up! If you have the basics, it will still be great. Here's my story: I started off with 4 red potatoes (I kept the good looking parts of the skin on) and several small home-grown carrots (but these turned out to be too few--my husband even said "Oh! Are there carrots in here?!"). I almost added some celery, but I found it to be too limp so I skipped it. But it probably would have added a nice dimension. I was also out of onion, so I used some garlic powder and (my personal all-time favorite) Mrs. Dash to help compensate for the loss. I used Olive Oil because it was on hand and I used turkey instead of ground beef--at the last minute. I had purchased ground beef just for this dish, but when I took it out of the fridge, it was a scary color of brown. I wasn't going to risk giving my family food poisoning! So I defrosted some ground turkey and saved the day. This is now a family favorite! I'm sure it will be great the next time I make it the right way--although I'll keep the garlic and Mrs. Dash--but for now, I can't wait for leftovers tonight!

(I just had to come back and say that I made this again with beef, celery, plenty of carrots and an onion and it was just as wonderful. Now I have to try to keep from making it every week. It's very filling and makes for lots of leftovers which is something I like in our house--less cooking and lots of lunches! We love it! Thanks!)

text:
I like this recipe, it's very attractive and colorful to eat, but it's very mild in both taste and texture.  I've made this three times.  Mashing the carrots would go faster if you had a food mill.  I added cooked frozen green beans to the burger mixture for texture.  Next time, I would cook the hamburger with seasoning, such as a seasoned salt and pepper, as well as add some Worcestershire sauce to the ketchup and broth.  I used chicken broth the last time I made it and this didn't seem to be a noticeable change from beef broth.  I also used Monterey Jack the last time instead of Cheddar on and in the potatoes, and that tasted good too.  I'll be making this again, but will try to add more flavor.

text:
Ok I made Shepard's Pie over 20 years ago. Maybe even 25 years ago. This very rarely happens to me as a matter of fact only twice in cooking since middle school have I made something so terrible I could not fix it. That was the case with my Shepard's Pie 20-25 years ago. A 9x11 Pyrex pan full with Wendy standing over me saying "I told you so."

That brings me to this week. I heard on K love , while they were playing their five songs (miss you Daniel Berry) , that the most Googled recipe on the internet is...................., Shepherds pie. This brought back the sour memories, and "I told yo so's. And I of course Googled , Shepard's Pie. This recipe is vindication for the epic fail 20-25 years ago. This is delicious even though I didn't have shredded cheese and used instead real cheese slices. I added a good tablespoon of cream cheese in the potatoes and followed comment suggestions with some extra garlic, of course, in he hamburger and maybe a couple of tablespoons is woshestershire sauce in hamburger.

This one is a keeper.

text:
Very tasty.  I took another member's advice and added 1/4 cup of Worcestershire sauce to the meat (after cooking), and I think that is crucial; otherwise the meat would be very bland.  I used 3 russet potatoes, and there was just too much potato for the dish, so you would be fine with 2 russet potatoes.  My daughter and husband liked it, although husband had to add hot sauce.  I really enjoyed the meet, and next time might just omit the potatoes altogether if I needed to get dinner on the table quickly.

text:
This is so good that I hide the leftovers in the fridge ( in a butter tub container) so I dont have to share them. 

I love Shepards pie.  I had never had it with carrots before and I was a bit skeptical but followed the recipe anyways. At first I was not sure if I liked the carrots but the next day when eating some leftovers my opinion changed. The carrots give it a sweet flavor and make the whole dish in my opinion.  I run my carrots through the food processor and make a puree. 

I always make more than one batch of this at a time and freeze the others so I can pull out later and bake.

I made some changes others suggested. I used 1/4 cup of Worcestershire sauce, a packet of brown gravy and one cup of water.I left out the carrots as I had none and also the beef broth. I added a cup and a half  of frozen peas, one can each of whole kernel corn,  green beans, and diced tomatoes.
My wife asked for seconds and thirds. ( she liked it) 
This was my first attempt at Shepherds Pie, and I am pleased.
My problem when I cook is I never follow a recipe, I will throw this or that in, keep this or that out. Never measure and can never remember how I made it. My wife says to write it down, but I am to busy.
I use a recipe as a guide only.

I halved the recipe and used 3 medium potatoes. I added 1/2 cup sour cream and lots of garlic and paprika to my mashed potatoes. I put all of the cheese on top instead of mixing it in. I used about 450g of grass-fed ground beef and used extra beef broth for the beef mixture, and added 2 tbsp of worcestershire sauce, a can of carrots and peas, and a can of corn niblets, and lots of extra garlic and cayenne pepper. I subbed tomato paste for the ketchup. It made 4 generous servings.

text:
Very good.  I made a few crutial changes to this recipe in order to arrive at perfection: add 1/4 cup of worstershire to the ground beef mixture before cooking. Also, added a can of beef consume (instead of 3/4 c. beef broth) and stir into the browned and floured meat mix to simmer for 5 min. Add a packet of hearty grav This gives the meat a little bit of gravy, which the mashed potatos love!  I add 8-10 oz. of frozen peas and carrots right on top of the meat mix and before the mashed potatos. It tasts great and adds color to the dish. Also put the cheese on top of the mashed potatoes!

Absolutely loved it. After reading all the reviews, I did make minor changes because it did sound like a bit bland for my taste. Used 1 lb ground lamb, didn't cover the base of the pan quite fully. Don't skimp on the onion! Tastes great in this. I used beef bouillon--mixed with potato water before adding to meat. Tip: if the layer of mashed potatoes seems 4x thicker than the other layers, don't fret. It'll taste fine. (I did add about 4 handfuls of spinach to my potatoes...) And leave some big chunks! Sneaking veggies into this is so easy--what a neat dish to take to lunch!

Made a couple of substitutions.  Cooked salted ground beef with onion, then added abour 4 baby bella mushrooms, chopped and 1 carrot chopped.  Didn't do the mashed carrot mix.  Used about 1 cup of broth instead of 3/4. Added 2 T worcestershire to the cooked meat, along with the 1 T ketchup.  Added about 1 c frozen carrots to the mix and put in a 1-1/2 qt round pyrex casserole.  Used leftover mashed potatoes to spread over top.  I'm refrigerating this before work, so I'll have bake it for about 45 minutes (I'm guessing).   The filling tasted good, so I have high hopes for tonight! Thanks for the recipe. text:
Loved it. This is a great recipe for Halloween. Very colorful with the cheese, carrot and mashed potatoe layer, looked like a candy corn. Think i will make again for Halloween.
Made a few changes. I cooked lean ground meat on the stove then drained. I sauteed onions red yellow and green bell pepper and garlic then mixed that with the beef. I sprayed the bottom of the glass baking pan. Put the meat and sauteed stuff in. Then i made a homemade cream of mushroom soup but  added flour to make thicker and added sour cream and cream cheese. Poured that on top. Did not use ketchup because my father in law can't have that. Then put tons of shredded medium cheeder cheese then a layer of mashed carrots with a touch of thyme. and the mashed potatoes on top with a touch of chedder to garnish.  Everyone devoured it. Just one servimg left out of a double recipe.

text:
Fantastic taste and appearance.  I upped the amounts a little so I would have leftovers.  I used 5 large potatoes and 1.5 lbs ground beef.  I added 1/4 Worcester sauce and a cup of beef broth to the ground beef after cooking to make the gravy.  I used a layer of cut, cooked carrots, and thawed peas and corn between the potatoes and beef - looked great with the contrasting colours.  This fit perfectly into a 2.5 ounce casserole dish.  I had to bake longer - for 30 minutes and an additional 5 on broil to brown the top nicely.

text:
Instead of beef, I used shredded leftover pork tenderloin (~ 1/2 lb), scaled the recipe down to 5, and it came out great! I sauteed the onion briefly, added the pork and flour, then the broth, some garlic and onion powder, ketchup and few dashes of Worcestershire sauce. It made a nice gravy with the meat. I used 1 chopped carrot that I boiled briefly, and mixed with a handful of frozen peas that I nuked briefly. The potatoes (used Yukon gold) came out so good, I could eat a whole bowl of those alone!  I added extra cheese (a Mexican blend) to the potatoes because why not? This was total comfort food for a cold, rainy winter day! Great recipe!

Excellent recipe to build on! I used a layer of mixed frozen carrots and peas that I boiled and added on top of the meat layer, then added potatoes and cheese. Also, add about 1/4-1/2 cup of Worcestershire and Club House gravy mix to the meat to add flavour, otherwise the meat layer would be absolutely bland. Very easy recipe to make, and easy to make a little leaner by swapping the beef with chicken.

text:
This is a great base recipe. 

I used duck stock instead of beef broth for a little different gravy depth. I saut√©ed crimini mushrooms in butter and garlic then started the layering with meat on that. (it gives the mushrooms a crispy crust-like depth) Then I used frozen corn on meat. Sprinkled Chipotle powder on that.

Mashed potatoes were next; made them with garlic powder, salt, fresh ground pepper, butter and whipping cream.

Topped with sharp cheddar cheese.

I cooked it all in one large cast iron pan so it can go straight from the stove top to oven until the cheese browned up nicely.

text:
I followed the previous reviewer's tips. I also used ground turkey/ground lamb.

Caution: 
1)	If you are using ground turkey, go easy on the Worcestershire sauce. Use a little less than ¬º cup. Also, go easy on salt. I did not use any in mine, because the combination of cheese, butter and Worcestershire sauce gave the right amount of salt in this dish.
2)	Do NOT overcook the potatoes. I made that mistake, because I thought it would help mashing them later, but no, it just made the pie soggy and it sank.
3)	Be aware that most brown gravy contains beef. I had to specifically look for one that doesn‚Äôt have it. Found it in Walmart.
4)	If you want this to be prepared fast, be ready to use 3 pots. Turkey, potatoes, vegetables.

Pot 1, boil potatoes with some salt. In Pot 2, I boiled carrots and every other leftover, mash-able vegetable which does not have a very distinct flavor from each other. This dish was a good way of getting rid cleaning out the fridge. I would not overdo it though. DO NOT OVERCOOK POTATOES (You can reserve the water from these 2 pots to be made into vegetable stock later). DO NOT ADD MORE THAN LISTED butter to the potatoes, because that makes the pie soggy too.

While those are boiling, I browned 1 cup of red onion, added 1.5 lbs ground, lean turkey. Added 2 tbsp of flour. Added 2 tbsp of ketchup. Added just a little below ¬º cup of Worcestershire sauce. Added 1 packet of brown gravy. Added 1 cup of water. A dash of paprika. Generous sprinkle of black pepper. L

text:
As mentioned in some of the other comments , onions and cheese do not belong in the potato topping. The onions are browned with the ground beef.   I simmered the meat in the beef broth for about 10 minutes before adding steamed peas and carrots  (not smashed)..   I used red potatoes with half-and-half for a creamier potato topping . I also used extra sharp cheddar for the topping.
The recipe listed has the basics, however if you have never made this before, you would be a bit confused.
Overall, I would make it again with my modifications.

Display Name:
amyzubyck

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I recently ordered Shepherd's Pie at an Irish-themed pub, which was totally out-of-character for me, but I wanted something I could share with my 1-year-old.  I ended up enjoying it quite a lot.  This past weekend, I had thawed out some ground beef with the intention of making meatballs, but didn't end up feeling like meatballs, so decided to find a Shepherd's Pie recipe instead.  I came across this recipe, and with a few tweaks, it turned out great.  As per feedback from other reviewers, I added 1/4 cup of Worcestershire sauce to the ground beef mixture.   And for the beef broth, I heated it and added Bisto brown gravy mix.  (I use "no salt added" broth at home, which can admittedly make food taste a bit bland at times.)  And finally, instead of using fresh carrots and mashing them, I used frozen peas, carrots and corn, boiled beforehand and DID NOT mash them.  In my opinion, the recipe "as is" warrants four stars, and with adjustments, five.  (I do think it's the Worcestershire sauce that made all the difference!)

text:
I have made this several times now, but I admit that I have changed it up a bit.   I follow the directions for making the ground beef mixture, but then I add a couple cans of veggies to the meat  instead of layering them on top. Green beans, corn, and carrots  all work well.  When I don't have beef broth, I use chicken broth instead and that seems to work fine.  Topping with instant mashed potatoes is much easier than homemade, unless I have leftovers to use The cheese on top is optional, but is pretty good.  makes for an easy, comforting meal!

Display Name:
Laura Garrison

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3369910.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this a whole bunch of times, and it's my favorite shepherd's pie recipe. I've gotten rave reviews on it. I don't even order shepherd's pie in most restaurants anymore because most can't hold a candle to this recipe. I made it as instructed first (I always do) and I give the recipe as written 5 stars. I have tweaked it over the years, partly based on personal preference and partly based on convenience. I've made it with instant mashed potatoes (I know-*gasp*, but when time is a factor it helps). I've added a brown gravy packet and some worcestershire (please forgive the spelling) sauce to the meat after it's cooked. I almost always use ground turkey instead of beef, so this helps jazz it up a little. And I almost always double the recipe because it gets gobbled up so quickly. And I stopped mashing the carrots, it takes extra time and I find sliced carrots more visually appealing anyway. I noticed in the photo what appear to be peas, so I tried throwing peas in with the carrots and that's yummy too, if you like peas.
Review:
Rating:
5

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
15360471
Display Name:
Barb Atkinson
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2061416.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this recipe because it was easy and tasty. I made a few changes based on some of the reviews I read and just out of sloth, necessity, and personal preference. I added a bit of Worcestershire sauce to the beef while I cooked it. Then, instead of dicing up an onion (this was both lazy and my last onion was looking very sad) I mixed 1 and a half cups of no salt added beef broth with 1 and a half tbsp of onion soup mix and then whisked in 2 tbsp of flour. Since I'm not a fan of carrot mash, I just tossed some frozen mixed veggies in with the beef when it was browned. When the veggies had more or less warmed up, I poured in my broth mixture in and let it simmer until it thickened, stirring frequently. I used red potatoes and left the skins on (because I like the texture) and mashed them with some melted butter and sour cream, then added the cheese.
It turned out really well and I will certainly be making it again.

text:
Great baseline recipe, very flexible. Worcestershire and garlic are a must for me, adjust for your tastes. This time I was out of carrots but added frozen peas, and some chopped tomato that needed to be used.  At least double the ketchup.
I make a packet of store gravy in the pan I cooked the meat in, to get all the yummy fond AND less dirty dishes.
Boxed instant potatoes are perfect for topping. I doctor it with garlic powder and dollop it on top to form irregular piles, and a blast from the broiler instead of a few minutes bake time makes it golden. Top with chopped green onions.

text:
this was fantastic- the perfect comfort food for my family. i actually wish that i had doubled the recipe & will do so next time because the leftovers were so yummy. i did tweak the recipe a bit after reading other's reviews: 
-added a hefty pour of worcester sauce & a packet of brown gravy mix, also a healthy squeeze of ketchup
- i used two bags of frozen vegetables (peas, carrots & corn) steamed & then added as the layer on top of meat. i used mashed potatoes that i had leftover from christmas, these were super rich & delicious (made with cream cheese, butter, parmesan). i waited until the last 10-15 minutes to add a couple of cups of shredded cheddar on top 

so while i do think this is a good base recipe, i would strongly encourage you to jazz it up & add to it to mix in more vegetables & flavor

text:
The recipe as is gets 4 stars due to the meat being a little flavorless as is. I had to add some diced fresh garlic, a couple tablespoons of Worcestershire sauce, couple tablespoons of soy, teaspoon of salt and pepper to get it to have a hearty taste. I added a little extra water for more gravy but I think next time I make this I will up the meat to 2lbs ground beef. I made it in a large casserole dish, and the meat just barely covered the bottom. I need it to be more meat, less potatoes next time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a delicious recipe, but I am only giving it 4 stars because of one thing: the carrots. When I try a recipe for the first time I always try to follow it EXACTLY so I can give it a proper and fair review. So when I tried this recipe as written, it was pretty good...but we didn't like how the only veggie was carrots, and my husband hated especially that they were mashed. The flavor of the meat is great (like some other reviewers I added about 1 Tbsp. Worcestershire sauce) so I knew this was a recipe we just needed to doctor slightly to our tastes. I used a frozen veggie mix that contained cut green beans, corn, peas, and diced carrot. Just perfect! That small adjustment made this a 5 star recipe in my books. So unless you're crazy for carrots, I'd suggest making a similar swap. Happy eating!

text:
One of my favorite recipes. Very easy to make and very tasty. I did make some minor substitutions because of family preference. I omitted the onion, peas and carrots and used corn and green beans instead (frozen). Also, to make things quicker, I used instant mashed potatoes. Doubled the cheddar cheese. Instead of adding ketchup, beef broth and flour, I used a packet of brown gravy, 2 tablespoons of worchestire sauce and 2 tablespoons  steak sauce. I also seasoned the meat with onion powder and garlic powder for more flavor.

text:
I had to improvise with this recipe because I was out of beef broth, so instead I used an equal amount of cream of mushroom. To flavor up the beef, I added 4 cloves of garlic (we love garlic), a dash of cumin, dash of parsley and a dash of Jamaican allspice. Oh and I used steamed veggies and left them in whole slices. All in all, it's amazing! By far one of my favorite recipes. Can't wait to try to original when I have the ingredients and compare ;)

Update, I have tried the original recipe and I still love this recipe, made it 4x now :) I'm going to try some of the recommendations in the other reviews below too.

text:
I'm making this right now actually (potatoes are boiling). Yes I made some personal changes and really isn't that what cooking is all about? 
I went with the Worcester 1/4 cup and the gravy  package and mixed in a half can of corn nibblet's 
A few twists of Jamie Oliver hot chilly peppers, Montreal steak spice a few shakes a dash or two of red wine to the raw meat let that sit for about 30 min.
Spread that meat mix after browning in my baking dish and spread a full can of cream corn on top when the potatoes are done I'll add butter sour cream and a bit of heavy cream with minced garlic mash and spread on top add the cheese and bake 30 min. 
I'll come back and let you know how it turned out.

text:
Delicious and easy starter recipe.  I used 3lb of Russet potatoes.  I found that they needed some milk and another 2 tbsp butter to achieve the right texture and flavor.  For the meat, I had 1lb ground beef so used 1 bag of frozen veggies instead of the carrots.  I didn't measure everything carefully so that might have impacted this, but I needed close to 2 cups beef stock, 2 Tbsp ketchup, added 2Tbsp Worcestershire sauce and some garlic powder.   My family loved this comfort meal on our cold winter night.

userID:
17388903
Display Name:
SimplyHere
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
3
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good! I had a few changes though:

1.  I don't drain the grease, I add a little extra flour and use a little beer to make a sort of gravy. It goes great with the mashed potatoes. 

2. I also added some vegetables, like peas-- and I mixed in my barely mashed carrots right before I put it in the oven instead of doing a layer. 

3. Make sure you go low and slow on those onions, they need to be soft and savory. Don't cook the ground beef too hard either. I used 80/20, but I think anymore fat would've been too greasy. 

Quick tip ! I suck at making a nice layer of mashed potatoes on top, so here's what I do:

Put a huge piece of wax paper in the dish you're going to bake in. Throw the mashed potatoes in there and get another piece of wax paper to put on top. Smush it into a nice layer and pick up your mashed potato layer by the edges of the wax paper. Throw your filling in the baking dish, and pull off one of the wax papers. Do a nice, quick flip to get the mashed potatoes in there, and remove your other layer. Two caveats here though-- you lose a bit of mashed potato to the wax paper and this only works well with nice thick mashed potatoes. I like mine to be just mashed enough to get the butter, sour cream, and salt mixed in well, those little bits of unmashed potato in the bites are SOO good. But this is definitely a favorite, and a good dish for parties. Not too expensive either.
Review:

text:
Perfect winter evening dish. I made this for the family and every bite was devoured. 

A few changes:  After browning the beef/onions and draining it, I set aside  the drippings in the pan, added butter  & flour and made a rue. From there I used the beef broth to make a small amount of gravy. Then I added the beef/onions back in. Also, I added some frozen peas atop the carrots. Lastly, I would add a potato of two more for more mashed potato topping. And going heavier on the cheese never hurts. I think I ended up using 1/2 cup. 

Thanks for a delicious recipe. It's a keeper!

text:
add 1/4 cup of Worcestershire to the ground beef mixture before cooking. Without this, the meat is too bland. Also, add a packet of brown gravy mix to 1 cup of water (instead of 3/4 c. beef broth) and stir into the browned and floured meat mix to simmer for 5 min. This gives the meat a little bit of gravy, which the mashed potatoes love!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-12-12T10:00:19.793
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
15010340
Display Name:
Eat
isPro:
False
followersCount:
23
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
170
favoritesCount:
253
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2701519.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I searched and searched for a recipe that included all the extras I wanted but couldn't find one. They all needed tweaking, but I think this was the best base recipe. The following changes made this recipe perfect for me:

1) Mix 1/4 cup Worchestire sauce in to ground beef before browning
2) Boil potatoes and carrots together until very soft (20 -25 min)for easy mashing.
3) Add 3 tbsp sour cream, 1/2 cup milk, 1 minced garlic, 1 tbsp butter, salt , white pepper and 2 tbsp fine chopped green onions to mashed potatoes. Leave Cheddar cheese out of it.
4) Add 2 or 3 minced garlic cloves and 1 chopped onion to pan when browning ground beef. 
5) Add 1 cup total frozen green peas and corn to ground beef after step 3 is complete.
6) 1 packet of gravy mix with one cup water instead of beef broth
7) Add enough shredded cheddar to cover top of pie. Bake covered at 375 for 15 min, 5 min uncovered and then broil for 3-4 min.
8) 2 tbsp of ketchup instead of 1.

This is a great basic recipe. I always read the reviews and wing a few things.  I loved the idea of adding fine chopped onions to the potatoes. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I changed the recipe a bit but my husband really liked it. I cooked and seasoned each layer separately. I saut√©ed in butter 1 small onion chopped and 4 garlic cloves diced, added ground beef, salt, pepper, paprika, and Worcestershire. When the ground beef was done, I removed everything from the pan and made a roux with the drippings and the flour. I cooked the roux long enough to make sure the flour would be 'cooked' added chicken broth (I don't like canned beef broth and I always have organic chicken broth on hand).  I turned down the heat and cooked the gravy - stirring constantly - until it thickened, seasoned the gravy with salt and pepper and just a dash of paprika and poured it over the meat mixture. I drained a can of sweet corn, added it as the next layer and then I added chopped red bell pepper on top of that. I added my left over mashed potatoes,  grated cheese on top and baked as instructed. I like seasoning the layers separately to make sure that nothing is too bland or missing something for my husband. I like this recipe because it can be adjusted so easily to match the taste of anyone you are feeding.

userID:
2159911
Display Name:
Lily
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

45

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2169404.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Brilliant recipe! I modified the recipe due to ingredient availability and taste preference. I browned about one and a half cup of coarsely chopped onion, then added a 1/2 lb mixture of half lean ground turkey (99% FF) and half lean ground beef (94% FF) (along with the called for ketchup, salt, pepper) - to which I had added worcestershire sauce (est 1/4 cup), a bit of red cooking wine (est 2 tbsp), 3 pressed garlic cloves, bit of red pepper flakes (est 1/8 tsp), herbs de provence, and garlic powder. After the meat had cooked, I then added about half a packet of brown gravy/water (per packet instructions). I simmered the gravy/meat mix until the sauce began to thicken, at which time I added steamed peas. Then I layered into a glass dish and topped with mashed potatoes (I was short on time, so I used quickly-made garlic mashed potatoes with a bit of thinly sliced onions). I topped with fat-free mozzarella cheese and baked for about 15 minutes. 

In my rendition of this recipe, I omitted the flour (the gravy did the thickening), carrots (didn't have any), homemade mashed potatoes (quick-fix), broth (substituted gravy), and cheddar cheese (used mozzarella). I added red cooking wine, worcestershire sauce, fresh pressed garlic, and lots of assorted spices. 

Next time, I may use a smidge less worcestershire sauce & Herbs de Provence and bit more wine. I found the recipe to be very forgiving, as I didn't measure most of my ingredients as I tossed them in. Turned out  fabulously!
Review:

5

We went with using frozen peas and carrots, per some reviews, and cooked them in a steamer basket over the potatos; next time I would just add them to the beef mixture to cook. Used minced green onions in mashed potatos. Added 2 cloves of crushed garlic, a few dashes of rosemary, marojam, thyme and worcestershire sauce in the beef. userID:
14184283
Display Name:
Angie Bunn
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1399641.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out awesome! I am a vegetarian, so obviously I made some changes. Instead of the ground beef, I used the original Yves veggie ground round. I heated up half a tablespoon or so of olive oil in a pan and put the veggie ground round in, and broke it up and heated it for a few minutes. I then spread that out over the bottom of a 2 & 1/2 liter casserole dish. Next, I layered one batch of homemade mushroom gravy. I got the recipe from the ohsheglows vegan food blog, if you google ohsheglows mushroom gravy you'll find the recipe. Then the mashed carrots, then I added frozen corn. I didn't measure how much, just enough to cover the carrots. Then the mashed potatoes, then the cheese! I ended up doubling the amount of cheese I put on top, about half a cup total. Maybe a bit more. My boyfriend and I love cheese so next time we will double the amount in the mashed potatoes as well. In the oven it went for about 17 minutes, then I switched it to the broiler on low for a few more minutes to melt the cheese more. Honestly I could not tell it wasn't real meat! My boyfriend is not a vegetarian and he says he likes it better than regular meat, it's less greasy. Great recipe. Obviously I omitted the meat, ketchup, and other ingredients added to the meat to make the gravy.

I made this for my partner's birthday since it's his favorite. He really liked it, but it tasted pretty simple to me. I did accidentally forget to add the ketchup (which I was going to use tomato paste anyway), but the only other changes I made were that I didn't put mashed carrot on, and I put sweet potato on one half of the pie and regular potato on the other. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious, easy, and flexible.  I used ground turkey, chicken broth, frozen mixed veggies, pepper jack cheese, and red potatoes because it's what I had on hand.  I did use about a quarter of a teaspoon of salt in the ground turkey mix and some Worcestershire sauce for flavor.  I made the mashed potatoes my usual way, with a whole lot of butter, some milk and some garlic, salt and pepper to taste.  While my son rated it 4 stars, I give it 5 stars for flexibility and being an easy weeknight dinner, especially if you make the potatoes and/or ground meat mix ahead of time.  I'll be making this again.  :)  Thanks, Jacquie.

text:
This recipe was a success. My boyfriend ate it all up and loved it from the first bite. I only cook for him and I'm always careful in the recipes I pick because anything too "complicated" to the taste buds confuses him. I added some worcestershire sauce and frozen vegetables and a bit more flour + broth because I'm pretty sure I used 3 1/2 pounds of lean ground beef. I used some leftover mashed taters and some new ones and it tasted great. First time I've ever had "shepherd's" pie, I'm actually going to try making actual shepherd's pie with lamb some time. This recipe was really simple and very tasty.

text:
Yum yum. I used ground turkey instead of beef but kept everything else almost the same. Looking at the recipe, I thought it would be a bit plain so I added extra peas and corn and also mixed up a special sauce of my own for the beef which included tomato sauce, ketchup, mustard, flour, vinegar, soy sauce, garlic powder, sugar, and also a bit of a curry roux. It was absolutely amazing!! The mashed potato was very delicious too however, I must have used HUGE potatoes or something because the ratio of meat to potato was a bit off; there wasn't a lot of meat to complement the large amount of mashed potato on top. Next time, I will buy more meat.

text:
Fantastic recipe.  Who cares that it's not traditional Shepherds pie.  I like it.  I did however make a few changes and additions.  I followed the recipe but added two large cloves of garlic when I sauteed the onions. I used vegetable stock instead of beef.  I added an extra 1/4 cup of water and sprinkled extra flour to thicken the gravy.  a few splashes of Worcestershire sauce is a must.  I did mash the carrots but they ended up being chunky ( tasted great ) and added some frozen peas to the veg layer.  It was a family hit.  I saved it

A very good recipe to start with. I used corn instead of carrots and instant mashed potatoes (makes it a much faster meal to prepare). I also added a tbsp of Worcester sauce as the ketchup & beef broth gave it very little flavor. I mixed the born in with the beef before spreading into casserole dish, adding a layer of cheese, then mashed potato and then one more layer of cheese. We use to use the clubhouse shepherds pie sauce, but hubby likes this one much better.

text:
My husband and company devoured this dish.  Two helpings each.  I did change it a little, though.  I accidentally overcooked the potatoes while caring for my toddler so I added sour cream, half and half, and white velveeta to the mixture to stiffen it up, yet keep it creamy.  I topped the potatoes with a little Italian seasoning and some garlic powder.  I completely omitted the carrots.   I added a can of canned mushrooms and 3/4 lb bag of frozen corn to the meat mixture.  I also used another reviewer's advice and used 1/4c worcestire and crushed garlic while cooking the meat mixture. Also, I baked it a little longer than 20 minutes.  I waited for the top to golden brown nicely.  It was a fantastic hit!

text:
Excellent base recipe, but there's no way this dish, from start to finish, is ready in 50 minutes. "Prep time 30 minutes" only possible if many steps are completed in advance. The results are well worth the 2 hours, from start to finish, prep time - multiple pots, pans and utensils needed. Used advice of other reviewers (sour cream, parsley & garlic added to 50/50 potato/parsnip combo; garlic, fresh thyme, tomato paste. worcestershire & white wine added to meat minus catsup; added peas & corn to mashed carrots; sprinkled paprika on top of cheese before baking). Made St Pat's Day a celebration - very yummy. A real comfort food and options are endless.

text:
Our modifications, first run:

1 - Swapped 1/2 of carrots out, mixed with frozen peas instead.
2 - Added 2 cloves of garlic (some to beef, some to potatoes)
3 - Add 2 tbsp "Bulldog" sauce (like thick Worcestershire)

This was really delicious, but the beef needed a touch more salty/savory flavor for our taste.

Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a recipe to use up left over mashed potatoes and this one fit the bill perfectly as I had all of the ingredients in the fridge! I made some changes based on previous comments including browning ground beef with onion and garlic and chopped celery and then simmering with a mixture of 1/4 cup worstershire, 3/4 cup beef broth and 2 T flour. I layered the beef mixture a bag of frozen veggies (carrots, peas, green beans, carrots and lima beans) and the cold mashed potates. It cooked a little bit longer than 20 minutes (maybe because the veggies were frozen and the potatoes cold) but it was worth the wait! Both my husband and 13 year old son loved it and had seconds, not much left over for my lunch!! Yum a great recipe.

great recipe. i read some of the other reviews and have to agree that tweaking is necessary for individual tastes. i like flavor in my meals and so made the mashed potatoes the way  i like them and used fresh chunks of carrots and peas mixed into the browned beef vs mashed carrots and no veggies. i added extra cheese - hey! i like cheese! i used lean ground beef and no added salt ( enough in the cheese) and added some rosemary and some other fresh thyme and oregano... definitely will make during the fall/winter as a hearty easy comfort dinner meal.

This is a great base recipe for Shepard's pie.  I gave it 4 stars because we made some changes to suit our tastes.  Added 3 cloves of garlic to the meat and potatoes. Display Name:
squirrelgirl22

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an average dish--not awesome, but not bad either.  The proportions resulted in too much potatoes on top for too little filling.  Additionally, the dish was rather bland.  I would use this recipe again but with a few alterations: (1) use half the called for potatoes, (2) season the meat with Worcester sauce instead of generic ketchup, and (c) continue to not mash the carrots and add peas as well.

I did really enjoy the taste of the potatoes.  I used half a tbsp of onion powder, half a tbsp of garlic powder, and the cheese and butter as called for.  It was VERY tasty.  I just might use this part of the recipe for all of my mashed potatoes going forward!

text:
This shepherd's pie is SO good!  I have been searching for a good recipe for years now to satisfy my picky husband, and this is now his birthday request dinner :)  I love the carrots under the mashed potatoes, gives it a great flavor.  I don't boil them though, you lose too many nutrients that way so I just dice them and steam- it takes the same amount of time.  The only ingredient change I make is the beef- I make the recipe on this site for 'Slow cooker Italian Beef' pretty frequently, which makes a lot of leftovers, so I use that!  I still make this recipe as is, but I just add my already cooked beef to the onions.  It makes for a very flavorful dish and is a great way to use up my leftover Italian beef.  Love it!

text:
I altered this a bit the first time I made this for a very untraditional shepherd's pie just for time and convenience' sake, but I really do want to try it as written sometime too.  I browned the meat and onion with the worcestershire (as recommended), then drained it and added it to some carrots and peas I had boiled until tender.  To that I added a can of cream of mushroom soup and about a cup of shredded sharp cheddar, dumped it in a 9 x 13 (lightly sprayed with Pam) and topped with 2 cans of refridgerated biscuits (which I lightly coated with butter to help with browning).  My husband has already commented on the wonderful smell coming from the kitchen!  Baked at 375 for about 15-20 minutes (just until the biscuits were done) - and it really was yummy!
