I used the remaining beef broth to defrosted the frozen veg. in a bowl with the microwave. I seasoned the meat the way I like with salt, pepper, worcestershire sauce and cooked with onions. Then, I mixed flour in water before I put it in the meat mixture. I added the beef broth and the ketchup and hot sauce and let simmer for 5 min. I did my own twist to the mash potatoes the way I like it. I didn't sure cheddar cheese because I don't like the way it melts all hard. So, I used mexican shredded cheese and put paprika ontop.

Delicious! It was a BIG hit at the table and I'm definitely going to make it again for a upcoming potluck.
Small changes I made: For the mashed potato I used red potato and decided to omit the butter & cheese. Instead I added minced garlic and upped the amount of onion. I sprinkled cheedar cheese on top about 5 mins before it was done cooking.
Instead of mashing the carrots, I cut them into small pieces and cooked in with the ground beef (which was seasoned with cayenne pepper, black pepper and fresh garlic). I also added green peas for color and taste. 

Thanks again for this awesome recipe!

text:
Family loved it!!! Basic recipe was great. However  the second time I added a few things, when cooking the beef, I added 1.5 cups mushrooms and two cloves of garlic finely chopped, also omitted the salt.  When beef was cooked, I added peas and corn. When boiling the potatoes tossed in a garlic clove which I leave in and mash with the potatoes, again omitted the salt.  Since I cook for two young children the more veggies I can jam into a recipe the better. Plus by adding more garlic I can eliminate salt.... it helps that my family loves garlic.

userID:

Display Name:
Brandi Fink

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1206969.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great basic recipe that lends itself well to personal adaptation. I used all the listed ingredients and added some things to suit my family's taste:   I sauted one large onion and a large clove of garlic with the ground beef, and I cooked the mushrooms with it in the pan. I also seasoned with a No-Salt seasoning blend, some garlic pepper, and a couple dashes of Emeril's Original Essence.  I also reduced the number of carrots and added some frozen mixed veggies in the veggie layer. I did NOT mash the carrots and left them sliced so my toddler could eat them more easily.  Following previous suggestions, I added 1/4 c. Worcestershire, and I increased the broth to 1 cup. b/c mine got a little dry from simmering it longer than the instructions.  When mashing the potatoes, I added milk, butter, salt, and pepper.  I used a 3qt. casserole dish, which made a thinner pie, but I think I added too much, so it wouldn't fit as well in my 2qt dish. Hehe!  I waited for the potatoes to start to get golden before topping with cheese.  My hubby LOVED it, and we will definitely be making it again! Thanks for the recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the direction of a previous comment. Instead of the ground beef I used ground turkey (you can't even tell the difference in my opinion) I did add several splases of Worchestire sauce while the meat was cooking and used more onion than suggested with some minced garlic.  Instead of using the beef broth I used 1 pkg of brown gravy mix mixed with 1 cup of water.  I added the gravy mix after the ketchup.  I let that get to a boil and then I added frozen peas and carrots.       All I used for the potatoes was boxed potatoes, I used Garlic Mashed Potatoes and added cheddar cheese in the potatoes and then added cheddar cheese on top.  It was delicious and next time I think I might add some corn with the peas and carrots.  This is definitely a redo!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent! As suggested by others, I think the key to this dish is a full-flavored, robust meat base. I used a mince for this (extra lean gd beef (or bison) would work just as well), browned with chopped onion. Cooked gently with 1 1/2 c. l/s stock, adding 2 TB ketchup, 2 TB Worcestershire, 1 TB Dijon mustard, thyme, garlic powder, s&p. Thickened with flour/water. I also added 1 c. colby jack to mashed potatoes, and dusted the top with paprika. Definitely not bland.

userID:
3937336
Display Name:
jezebel
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

3
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe.  I made a few changes, just due to what I had on hand.  Instead of the ketchup, I added about I cup of home-made bolognese sauce.  We make a big batch of this every wek, so we always have some on hand.  I used frozen mixed vegetables (peas, corn, carrots) and added to the beef as it was browning.    I mixed about 1 teaspoon of butter and one teaspoon of flour together over low heat and added i cup of beef broth.  This made a nice gravy that I mixed into the beff mixture.  Then I put the whole mixture into the casserole and into the oven on low heat for a couple of hours... the flavours came together nicely.  I would imagine that a slow cooker would work just as well.  For the potatoes, I used roasted garlic and added it to the mash.  When I'm in a fussy mood, I use a large star-tip and piping bag to put on the mash.  It looks pretty and keeps the potatoes nice and fluffy on top of the meat, instead pressed into the meat as happens with the spoon and spread method.  Overall, big hit and can be modified to suit any taste.

text:
I changed up the meat layer a bit. First I browned the ground beef and drained it. In the same pan I sauted diced onions until they are soft. Then I add the garlic and cook that all together for about a minute. I ADD A PACKET OF BROWN GRAVY MIX plus the recommended amount of water (it really makes the meat taste juicy). I let that cook until it thickens. I add the meat to the gravy mixture as well as a few cups of frozen peas and carrots. Then assemble the sheperd's pie as usual.

This recipe was very easy, and my family thought it was delicious. I substituted frozen mixed veggies for carrot mash and dryed onion flakes to mash potatoes. I added 2 tsp. minced garlic to meat and onion mixture. I also topped veggie layer with a mixture of condensed cheddar cheese soup and 1/2cup of starchy potatoe water. The meat I used was a mix of half gr. turkey and half gr. venison. I have three small children and it only took me 30min. to prepare, which is wonderful and very yummy! Thanks

This was delicious!  I followed other reviewers recommendations and added 1/4 cup Worchestershire to meat.  I omitted beef broth and added 1 packet of beef gravy and 1 cup of water. Thanks Jacquie!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed this! I made a few modifications so that's why it got 4 stars. I used half a pound ground turkey and half a pound ground pork instead of beef. I cooked the meat in onions and garlic instead of just onions. I also seasoned the meat with garlic powder, onion powder, salt, and pepper, then added a few splashes of Worcestershire. I double the ketchup. I think this was really necessary to give the meat some flavor. I used the "Garlic Mashed Red Potatoes" recipe for the potato topping. We use that recipe a lot (with red and Idaho potatoes) and it made the topping extra tasty! I also used cut up baby carrots, and some canned corn and green beans (drained) for the veggies. This recipe was a really great starting off point, so thanks for sharing! It really tasted better the second day!

Display Name:
SnL

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
VERY time consuming!  But does taste delicious.  The prep time takes about 1 hour, and that is with my husband helping too.  We use 3 large potatoes instead of 4 and green onion instead of the finely chopped onion.  When mashing the potatoes, I add in 1/4 cup sour cream, garlic powder and some milk until it is the consistency that I like. I always slice the carrots, and cook them in the microwave in a bowl with water. I add 2 cloves of minced garlic to the beef, skip the flour and beef broth, use 2 tbsp of ketchup instead of 1, and add in 2 tbsp worcestershire sauce, making sure to drain the meat well before adding those flavourings.  I change the layering a bit too by adding a thin layer of cheese right after the meat. I add 1 cup frozen peas and layer them on top of the carrots.   To finish it off I sprinkle the cheese on top of the potatoes and then sprinkle paprika on top of that.  It may be a lot of changes, but if I am going to spend all that time making it I like to cater the recipe to our tastes.

text:
Excellent recipe that I will be sure to make again! Like everyone, I made changes that appealed to me: I omitted the onions from the mashed potatoes and added fresh parsley and minced garlic, as well as the butter and some skim milk until it reached my desired texture. I used ground lamb instead of beef and omitted the ketchup, using 1/4 cupf of Worchestershire  sauce and thyme. Next time I will add the Worchestershire after it's cooked and drained for added flavor, although it still had flavor. Instead of boiling and mashing carrots, I just poured frozen mixed vegetables (carrots, green beans, peas and corn - straight from the freezer) on top of the meat mixture and then topped that with the mashed potatoes and cheese. Next time I may do a layer of fresh mushrooms as well. This was a great, hearty meal that was good on the second and third day as well!

city:

text:
it's been awhile since I started making this dish... but we have this for dinner at least every couple of weeks. It's delicious! I made a few changes to mine though... -I took the advice of another reviewer & add 1/4 cup woshishire sauce to the hamburger, except I add it after it's cooked & drained (it adds a good flavor to the otherwise bland meat) - same reviewers advise: instead of the beef broth I use a packet of brown gravy mix mixed with 1 cup water.  -I also use a little bit more butter in the potato mix (about 3 tablespoons... we love butter!) & I add a little more ketchup to the meat (total of  tablespoons)  -Instead of the mashed carrots I just add about 3 fresh... peeled, chopped & boiled (about 15 minutes) carrots & throw in about 2 cups of cooked (about 8 minutes) frozen peas to the meat mixture before I top with the potatoes.  Everyone loves this dish. Our 2 daughters (ages 11 & 5) love it too. 5 stars because this dish has absolutely become a family favorite!

text:
This was my first attempt at Shepherd's Pie. I will definitely make it again with a few changes...first off, no onions in the mashed potatoes...not matter what you do, they're still crunchy which messes up the whole texture...also, I will add more seasoning to the meat; it needed something extra. Overall a good (and pretty easy) meal, it is also much better the second day after all the flavors have melted together. Note: I did put carrots, peas and celery in mine!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great, and my fiance (picky eater) also loved it! I've always thought shepherd's pie was a little blah, but I loved your idea with the mashed carrots and cheesey potatoes, so I gave it a try.  I only give this FOUR stars though, because I did make a few changes, and added some seasoning as most reviewers suggested.  Firstly, I omitted the onions since the SO hates them...I snuck in some onion powder though (apparently it's the texture that gets him), and sauteed up some fresh garlic in the onion's place.  I also added a bunch of fresh chopped parsley, and sauteed the meat in the seasoning mixture.  I left out the ketchup per my own preference, in favor of about 1/4 C worcestershire, and added salt and pepper to taste.  And of course, I just couldn't imagine a shepherd's pie without peas and corn (maybe this is a regional thing?), so I put those between the meat and carrots.  In the end, this had TONS of flavor!  You just need to add your own flare, it's a very versatile recipe that would go great with a number of seasonings.  Thanks for giving me an idea for sheppherd's pie that I enjoy!

text:
Followed the recipe as written and it was delicious! Very filling also. Only downfall is the amount of dishes that are created with it...lol *UPDATE* So I modified it to only use minimal dishes, which only eliminated 1 but that counts in my book...Instead of boiling potatoes and carrots seperately I boiled them together with the onion. Mashed together as well, my son is picky and loves potatoes so this made it so he couldn't really pick around the potato. I don't completely mash I 'smash' so you get chunks of each for a good mouth feel. Very delicious! I also sprinkled a little salt and pepper over the potato/carrot mash before putting cheese on. This time around I didn't realize I had no cheddar so we used monterey jack cheese.

text:
This is a great basic recipe that can easily be adapted to suit your own tastes.  I boiled my carrots and potatoes together and mashed them together omiting the onion and cheese.  I browned the ground beef with the onion and some garlic.  Followed the rest of the recipe for making the sauce adding slightly more ketchup and some Worchestershire sauce.  I added some frozen peas and corn to the meat mix topped with the mashed potato/carrot mix and topped with shredded cheese.  Delicious comfort food that the entire family loved.

My husband who says he does not like shepherd's pie, loved this! My four year old loved it too. I made two versions, one with meat and a vegetarian version. The only changes I made were adding some Roasted Garlic to the potatoes. I also made two batches of each version and froze one for later.  The other I prepared and put in the refrigerator so all my husband had to do was put it in the oven while I was at work. The reheated leftovers were just as good too!

This recipe had gotten so many great reviews so I decided to make it for St. Patty's day last night.  I'm glad I made the gamble because my family lOVED it and there was barely any leftovers! I followed the tip of using the pkg. gravy and water in lieu of beef broth and added to ground turkey. I also added 2T of Worcestershire sauce.  The ketchup didn't sound appealing so I left that out. I used the frozen mixed veggies (coated w/ butter) from Trader Joes that I put under the mashed potatoes. I used a mixed blend of shredded cheese. I must admit, I also used the pre-made mashed potatoes from Costco. It was definitely a semi-homemade version but it was a huge success! I will definitely make it again - outside of St. Patty's Day.

text:
I am basically a complete beginner. My wife won't let me go into the kitchen. After I couldn't make a salad without screwing up, I was banned. My wife has to go to surgery tomorrow, so she's been down. I told her I'd try to make dinner for St. Patrick's Day, and she laughed.  I found this recipe and was able to do it start to finish and have wonderful results.  I followed the advice of SANDIEGOCINDY, and used a German brown gravy instead of the broth. I also added butter to the carrots. I added Meat Magic and Worcestershire sauce, as well as two cloves of garlic to the onions/meat, but didn't use the garlic in the potatoes. I did use a few tablespoons of sour cream in the potatoes, and a 1/2 a cup of mild cheddar.  At the end, I also sprinkled cheddar on top and put scallions.   Everything turned out well, but I was surprised that, even though in the back of my mind I thought it would be over-seasoned, it was "just right," or I should say, required a little salt for my tastes, but wasn't bland.  I didn't feel like Chef Ramsay, but I did feel like it was an excellent result for my first attempt, well, ever. Yeah, I suppose I'm sheltered.   Thanks for all of the advice and the recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/196073.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good.  I did modify it a bit.  I usually make mince and taties (meat and potatoes b/c my mother inlaw is from Scotland).  I decided to try this recipe b/c it is basically the same just put together and baked.  I only used 2 med./large potatoes (cut up), 1 tbs marg. and salt and pepper to taste (skipped the chopped onion and cheese).  I started the potatoes at the beginning and preheated the oven.  The potatoes were ready to mash by time the meat was cooked and the oven was preheated.  I skipped the carrot mash.  For the meat, I used one medium onion, about an 1/8 cup minced garlic (from the jar), ground beef, flour, ketcup, low sodium beef broth, 1/4 cup worchester sauce, a little onion powder, salt and pepper.  I added about a cup of frozen mixed corn and peas at the end before putting in a small round casserole dish.  I skipped the cook flour for 1 minute.  Just mixed in all the ingredients.  I also skipped cheese in the whole dish.  I basically followed directions 1, 3, 4, and 5.  Very good.  Thanks for the recipe (even though I modified it a little)!

text:
This recipe was very good but I made some modifications and took some shortcuts.  First I sauted the onion, then added the ground beef to brown. I seasoned with a mixture of garic salt, pepper, and salt.  Then I added a frozen bag of peas and carrots to the mix, a cup of water, and a brown gravy mix packet until it thickened up.  I cheated and used instant mashed potatoes, they were butter and herb flavored and topped those over the meat mixture.  Then I topped with shredded cheese and green onions and baked.  It was so good.

I think next time I will choose another recipe or spice this one up and forget the carrots...Instead I'll add frozen peas and carrots.

Hearty man food! I followed the advice of some of the other reviewers and cooked the ground beef with half a cup of Worcestershire Sauce when I cooked the beef. I also added milk and more butter to my mashed potatoes because I just think it's weird not to. 
I'm giving this recipe 5 stars, not because I was blown away by the taste, but because it's a dish anyone would like. I had my mother, my sister, and my boyfriend over when I made this. There was no leftovers!
Next time, however, I think I might try the beef gravy tip. I liked it enough to eat too much, but I still could have used a little more flavor.

This on it's own is just okay.  I added dry ranch seasoning mix and 2 tbsp sour cream to the mashed potatoes. To the meat I added some mushrooms, garlic powder, salt & pepper. Without all the seasonings I think it would have been very bland. Also if you like an even ratio of meat to potatoes, or maybe even a little more meat you'll want to change it. I only used 3 small russets and it was more than enough. I would recommend only 2 potates for 1 lb of meat.

userID:
3070341
Display Name:
Kelly King Judd
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
145
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1941364.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this meal because it was an easy midweek recipe for ground beef.  This is how I cooked the dish:
Boiled chopped potatoes in a covered dish for 10min. while I was browning the meat.  Then I made the mashed potatoes with milk, sour cream, butter, pepper, salt and garlic (all to taste).  While making the potatoes I popped in a bunch of cut carrots into the microwave in a covered dish and cooked for 8 min.  Then I mashed the carrots up with milk and butter.  To the meat I was browning I added garlic powder, salt, ground pepper, onion powder (since I was out of real onions), almost a whole can of beef consume, 2 tbls. ketchup, 2 tbls. flour.  Be sure to taste test your beef mixture and see if it needs more salt, pepper, or garlic powder.  After the meat mixture was browned I added frozen corn, frozen peas, and a can of green beans.  I placed the beef mixture in a caserol dish then spread the mashed carrots on top of that then spread a layer of potatoes on top of the carrot mixutre.  Finally topped my dish off with shredded cheese.  My husband and I liked the meal for something "different".  It wasn't our favorite, but hubby says he wouldn't mind having it again.

text:
This turned out great - I took some of the other reviewer suggestions and did it with gravy instead of beef broth and I added a bit of Vermouth to that, as well as Worcestershire sauce. DELICIOUS! A great comfort food. It turns out great with ground turkey by the way, my boyfriend didn't even know he was eating turkey instead of beef! I didn't mash the carrots - I left them just chopped and cooked them a bit with the onions and then the turkey - they were crisp but not 'raw' tasting and not mushy, a healthy balance between the two. I'll be making this again when the weather dips below 80 here in the desert. ;)

userID:

Display Name:
LindaRae

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/116689.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read other reviews and tweaked mine a bit. I used 2 lbs ground chuck, browned with onions, 2 minced garlic cloves, and a few dashes of Worstershire sauce on Tuesday. On Wednesday I warmed the beef/onions, added about 2 Tbsps ketchup, a can of beef broth, a 1 lb pkg of frozen carrots & peas, a can of beef gravy, a packet of onion soup mix and about 1/3 cup of water. I let that simmer for about 10 minutes while I got the potatoes ready. Now here is where I cut a corner I shouldn't have. I mixed 2 pkgs of instant mashed potatoes. I should have made the Garlic Mashed Red Potatoes (found on this site). I also should have put this in a larger casserole dish than a 2 qt. Anyway, I topped it with a combo of shredded colby/monterey jack and baked for 20 minutes. My husband really liked it. He said it reminded him of a thicker beef stew with mashed potatoes on top.
I will make it again and keep tweaking it until I am more satisfied with it, perhaps using corn with the peas instead of carrots next time.

I FOLLOWED OTHER SUGGESTIONS, AND USED WORSCHIRE AND FROZEN VEGGIES. BUT INSTEAD OF BROTH I USED CONSOMME, (THOUGHT ABOUT FRENCH ONION SOUP). BAKED WHAT I NEEDED AND FROZE THE REST FOR LATER.

This is a good base recipe, I guess... just boring and BLAND.  I followed the recipe exactly - and added a healthy dose of worcestershire sauce to the meat, 'cuz I love the stuff.  I'm not fan of hot-n-spicy, and prefer a simpler flavor palette - but this recipe straight off the page is boring boring boring. 

I'd rather make tasty tacos in ONE pan in 30 minutes than this insipid dish in 90 minutes while dirtying three pots, two bowls, a baking dish, and a extra utensils.  Some of the suggestions in the comments are cool, like using peas and carrots and instant potatoes - but I need more FLAVOR.

text:
Pretty good, but not our favorite.  I made the mistake of cooking the potatoes and carrots together even though I planned to mash them separately -- dumb!  It was a messy, hot pain to separate the chunks after all was cooked.  I added 1/2 c. worcestershire and doubled the ketchup, plus added some green beans and cooked them in the meat mixture.  Added some sour cream to the potatoes -- they needed a LOT of salt to have much flavor, and we still needed to add salt to our helpings on the plate.  Again, not bad, but not terribly exciting, even with all the tweaking.

userID:
2811063
Display Name:
kiki
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
7

3

0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really yummy.   My tweaks:  In a 4.5 qt. oven safe sauce pan, I sauteed the onion, then added some pressed garlic.  I mixed the ground beef with 1/4 c. of worst. sauce, then added it to the onion and garlic to brown.  Lots of salt and pepper.  Then I added 2 cans of french style green beans to the meat, and then 1 pkg. of brown gravy and 1 cup water.  I boiled a big bag of carrots until soft, then mashed them with a half a stick of butter.   I whipped up 2 packages of four-cheese instant potatoes.  I layered the mashed carrots on top of the hamburger and green beans (in that same oven safe pan the hamburger browned in), then layered that with the mashed potatoes, and sprinkled a good layer of sharp cheddar cheese on top.  Popped it in the oven until melty and bubbly.   Good comfort food.  My husband wanted more gravy but I don't know that the layers would hold still if it was more saucy.
Review:

Wow - this was incredible! I keep kosher so the cheese was out. After reading all the reviews I came up with this - I browned the ground beef with the chopped onion then added 1 jar of beef gravy and stirred in about a handful of each: frozen corn, green beans, green peas & carrots.  I topped with homemade mashed potatoes with very little milk added so they were thick.  Then baked as directed.  My family really enjoyed it, especially my teenage daughter who hates everything these days.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/801488.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been searching for a while for a dish that my mother made when I was growing up and this is it! I followed other users' suggestions of browning the meat with 1/4 c. Worcestershire sauce and adding a pack of brown gravy to the meat. This made a nice thick sauce which was great with the potatoes. Put a thin layer of shredded cheddar on top of meat mixture, then 2 cans of green beans, followed by a cover of instant mashed potatoes (saves time!). Topped with more shredded cheddar. Yum!

text:
Great recipe- I did make some changes, and it turned out perfectly!  Hubby raved & our toddler ate all he could hold.  Instead of the beef broth, I used a cup of water & packet of beef gravy mix, and omitted the ketchup.  Instead of carrots I used green beans & peas.  I didn't have any shredded Cheddar, so I cut up some American singles, and that worked like a charm.  The gravy gave the beef some substance, and the American melted so wonderfully on top of it all.  Two thumbs up!

text:
This was suprisingly good.  I never thought I would like Sheperd's Pie but I was wrong.  I made mine a little different.  I used 1 lb. ground beef, 1 lb. ground sausage, 1 C beef broth, 2 tbls. Worchester sauce, and 1 tbls. of flour.  I left my carrots 1/2 mashed and 1/2 whole.  I blended them for 5 seconds just to get them a little mashed.  I topped mine with Mexican Cheese only b/c I did not have Cheddar Cheese.  It all turned out so well.  My 2 year old daughter had 2nd helpings!  I will make this one again and again.

Great recipe, husband ate it all up. 
I think the mushed carrots were kinda pointless, might as well just add frozen mixed vegis like others did and forget the mashed carrots altogether. Added worchestire and 2 cloves of garlic to meat(probably a little too garlicky for most but we are garlic fiends here). Also added sourcream to potatoes. I think what would really make the potatoes standout would be to also add maybe half to a whole small block of cream cheese.
  If none of the changes were made it most likely would of been to bland for my taste, hence the 4 stars.

text:
I made this recipe at home as a trial before maybe using it for a dinner series I'm catering. I usually make my everyday shepherd's pie with ground beef and packaged gravy, topped with corn and mashed potatoes - not very exciting! I was much more pleased with the gravy that forms with this recipe; it's got a great flavor. I'm not sure about the mashed carrot layer. It added a sweetness that I'm not sure I'm crazy about, and of course it does add more time to the prep. I'll probably leave that out next time and put in a layer of mixed veggies or corn. More effort than my usual recipe, but definitely worth it. I will be making it this week for my catered dinner. Thanks!

text:
This is a good recipe if you already have leftover mashed potatoes.  For me, it seemed like a lot of steps and dishes to wash.  My other problem was that the carrots (which I boiled for a long time) never got soft enough to mash with a fork.  Next time, I will wait until I already have mashed potatoes, and I will keep a can of carrots handy until I figure out exactly how to make them into mush.  I really had hoped to mix the carrot mush in with the meat so my 3-year-old wouldn't even notice it. But I will try it again with some alterations.

text:
This is a great, easy recipe. I usually omit the carrots and add kernel corn and/or green beans. I've also substituted sweet potatoes for the white potatoes (I recommend trying this sometime...it tastes really good and is better for you). I also add a whole onion to the meat and sometimes sliced mushrooms. I followed the advice of others and also added gravy mix to the "sauce". 

I've made this many times. It's a very versatile recipe, and you can add pretty much any veggie to it and it'll be delicious. Thanks for the recipe!

This really worked out nicely. I had left over mashed potatoes from last night's dinner, so I used them for the topping. Instead of carrots, I used fresh corn, (cut off the cob from our garden) and fresh green beans, also from the garden. I made the gravy using vegetable broth, added worchestire sauce, and ketchup. 

Delicious! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This turned out quite nice. My husband liked it, but said there might need to be a little more gravy. I cooked the carrots, but not long enough and I think I liked it that way because there was still some chunky carrots. I also added peas and for the mashed potatoes I used hot milk and butter to mash them. The onion was a little overpowering in the potatoes so I might just do the cheese next time. I used worcestershire sauce, but I don't think I'll do that again. I'll just add the ketchup. Overall a good recipe and actually tastes better the next day.

text:
I think this was a very good shepherd's pie! I have made it with the carrots, but once I had only frozen mixed veggies, so I popped that in the food processor to mash it after cooking and used it. I actually like that a lot better than the carrots! Not as pretty, but much more flavor, and healthier too! I also season my ground beef with garlic salt, emeril's essence, and my mashed potatoes with white pepper, butter, condensed milk (it makes it creamy), & a bit of garlic salt.

This is an excellant recipe...my family just loved it. My husband told me to double the recipe next time.
I followed another review, and instead of broth, I used brown gravy..which gave the ground beef mixture more flavor. I also added paprika and cayenne pepper to the beef. I didn't use the ketchup or brothe. I added a can of peas and carrots. I used cheddar and monterey jack cheese, and I sprinkled oregano on top. Great flavor...my husband wants me to make it again..like today.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made as described with the following adjustments: used frozen corn and peas (cooked) instead of carrots) and added a splash of worcestershire to the beef mixture.  The potatoes were excellent and the presentation was very nice, but I found the meat portion a little bland and thought it could have used more sauce/gravy to be a true Shepherd's Pie.  May try again with further adjustments, more seasonings, more gravy.
Update 2/15:  Made again following reviews.  Added 1/4 cup worcestershire, a packet of brown gravy mix, a cup of water and a splash of red wine to the beef mixture.  Used frozen peas and carrots (should have cooked a bit first as the carrots were a bit crunchy).  Added sour cream to potatoes and cheese only to top.  Very yummy on a cold winter night.

This was good, DH and I both enjoyed it.  I didn't add onion to the potatoes or mash the carrots, and I did add a can of corn but those were the only changes.  Next time I won't add the cheese to the top (we didn't think it was really needed) and instead will add a few splashes of worchestershire sauce to the top of potatoes and a couple of pats of butter. It's very good that way!!  Anyway, it seems like a lot of changes but that is what is so great about a recipe like this...you can always alter it to suit your tastes!
